education.title: What is a Personal Loan?
education.content1: A personal loan is money borrowed from a bank, credit union, or online lender that you pay back in fixed monthly installments over a set period, typically 1-7 years. Unlike mortgages or auto loans, personal loans are usually unsecured, meaning they don't require collateral.
education.content2: Personal loans can be used for almost anything: debt consolidation, home improvements, medical expenses, weddings, or emergency costs. Because they're unsecured, interest rates are typically higher than secured loans but lower than credit cards.

faq.question: What credit score do I need for a personal loan?
faq.answer: Most lenders prefer a credit score of 670 or higher for the best rates. However, some lenders offer loans to borrowers with scores as low as 580, though at higher interest rates.

faq.question: What's the difference between APR and interest rate?
faq.answer: Interest rate is the cost of borrowing the principal. APR includes the interest rate plus any fees, giving you the true cost of the loan. Always compare APRs when shopping.

faq.question: Should I pay off my loan early?
faq.answer: If your loan has no prepayment penalty, paying extra can save you significant money on interest. Even small extra payments add up over time.

faq.question: Fixed vs variable rate - which is better?
faq.answer: Fixed rates offer predictable payments. Variable rates may start lower but can increase. Fixed is usually better for longer-term loans.

faq.question: How do origination fees work?
faq.answer: Origination fees (typically 1-8%) are charged by lenders to process your loan. They're usually deducted from your loan amount.
